title: Kartik Purnima: The Full Moon Night the Gods Come Down to Bathe
excerpt: Diwali ends with Kartik beginning, and the month of Kartik is considered the most sacred of all months in the Vaishnava tradition. Its full moon â€” Kartik Purnima â€” is the crescendo: the night of Dev Diwali, when it is said the gods themselves descend to the banks of the Ganga to bathe in its waters. To witness it at Varanasi is to understand why people have called this river divine.

body.heading: The Month the Gods Love Most
body.text: Kartik â€” the eighth month of the Hindu lunar calendar, corresponding roughly to October-November â€” holds a special position in Vaishnava devotion that no other month quite matches. The Padma Purana devotes extensive passages to the month's significance, stating that a single act of worship, charity, or scripture recitation performed in Kartik carries the merit of thousands of such acts performed in other months. Kartik is specifically associated with Vishnu's awakening: he sleeps for four months during the Chaturmas period (from Devshayani Ekadasi in Asadha to Prabodhini Ekadasi in Kartik), and the entire month following his awakening is considered charged with his returned presence. The Tulsi plant â€” sacred to Vishnu â€” is worshipped daily in Kartik. Devotees bathe before dawn, light diyas in temples and on the banks of rivers, and observe the month with special austerities. Kartik Purnima, the full moon at month's end, is the culmination of these thirty days.

body.heading: Dev Diwali: The Festival of Light That the Gods Celebrate
body.text: Kartik Purnima is called Dev Diwali â€” the Diwali of the gods. According to tradition, on this night the thirty-three crore (330 million) deities descend to earth and bathe in the sacred rivers, particularly the Ganga. The ghats of Varanasi on Kartik Purnima are among the most extraordinary sights in India: step after step covered in thousands of earthen lamps, the river reflecting a river of light, boats floating between reflections, music rising from every direction, and the air heavy with incense and marigolds. The spectacle began as a private religious observance by Varanasi's Brahmin and merchant communities and has grown across centuries into one of the most visually stunning festival nights in the world. But it is not spectacle alone â€” the lamps are lit by individual hands, one by one, each one a private act of devotion within a collective act of wonder.

body.heading: Three Stories, One Full Moon
body.text: Kartik Purnima carries at least three significant mythological associations. First: it is the day Lord Shiva killed the demon Tripurasura â€” a triple-demon who had built three flying cities of gold, silver, and iron and used them to terrorize the universe. Shiva, in a single instant, destroyed all three cities with one arrow at the precise moment they aligned. This victory is called Tripurari, and Shiva is worshipped as Tripurari on this night. Second: it is considered the day Vishnu manifested as Matsya â€” the fish avatar â€” the first of the ten principal avatars (Dashavatara), who saved the Vedas and the sage Manu from a cosmic flood. Third: it is the day Guru Nanak Dev Ji, the founder of Sikhism, was born â€” and Sikhs around the world celebrate Gurpurab on this night, which often coincides with Kartik Purnima. Three faiths, three histories, one full moon.

body.heading: The Tulsi Vivah and the End of Chaturmas
body.text: The days just before Kartik Purnima bring another beloved ritual: Tulsi Vivah, the ceremonial marriage of the Tulsi plant (Holy Basil) to Lord Vishnu (in the form of the Shaligram stone). This typically happens on Prabodhini Ekadasi â€” the day Vishnu wakes â€” or on any day up to Kartik Purnima. The Tulsi Vivah is observed with the full ceremony of a traditional wedding: the plant is decorated, the Shaligram is brought in procession, mantras are recited, sacred fire is lit, and the seven circumambulations are performed. With this marriage, the wedding season officially opens: in many Hindu traditions, marriages are not performed during the four months of Chaturmas while Vishnu sleeps, and the first auspicious day for weddings is after Tulsi Vivah. Kartik Purnima thus marks not only the end of a sacred month but the beginning of the year's most celebratory season.

body.heading: Bathing Before Dawn and the River's Gift
body.text: The most meritorious practice of Kartik Purnima â€” and of the entire month of Kartik â€” is the pre-dawn bath in a sacred river, known as Kartik Snan. Devotees wake in the darkness, well before sunrise, and immerse themselves in the river while chanting Vishnu's names. In cities along the Ganga, the ghats are crowded by 4 AM on these mornings; in cities far from a sacred river, devotees add Ganga Jal (Ganga water) to their bath. The logic of Kartik Snan is that the pre-dawn hour â€” the Brahma Muhurta â€” is spiritually the most potent time of day, when the mind is clearest and the veil between ordinary consciousness and sacred awareness is thinnest. To immerse yourself in sacred water at that hour, in the month when the gods are most present, is considered an extraordinary gift â€” not to some external entity, but to your own capacity for clarity and peace.
